{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3492492,"name":"Miguel Ramos","username":"miguelsr","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/miguelsr/{size}/244931_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-25T18:19:51.132Z","cooked":"

Hey guys, anyone can help us with PID + Feedforward tuning?

we’re trying to tune an arm subsystem, with FF and PID. Basically, in another topic, we saw a “step-by-step” guide to finding the FF constants

We place the arm parallel to the floor, find the lowest kG value that holds the arm in that position

we find kV by dividing 1 by the maximum angular velocity we found

and we started trying to use the PID together, but for some reason, when the arm is in the vertical position (0 degrees) it has some oscillations, in addition to that when we are in horizontal and we go to vertical the arm, we have a large momentary overshoot , after a while, it corrects the overshot and returns to oscillating vertically

our code is below:

github.com

KryptonFRC9487/Krypton-FRC-Test/blob/main/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/ArmSubsystem.java

package frc.robot.subsystems;

import com.revrobotics.spark.SparkBase.PersistMode;
import com.revrobotics.spark.SparkBase.ResetMode;
import com.revrobotics.spark.SparkLowLevel.MotorType;
import com.revrobotics.spark.SparkMax;
import com.revrobotics.spark.config.SparkMaxConfig;
import com.revrobotics.spark.config.SparkBaseConfig.IdleMode;
import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.DutyCycleEncoder;
import edu.wpi.first.math.MathUtil;
import edu.wpi.first.math.controller.ArmFeedforward;
import edu.wpi.first.math.controller.ProfiledPIDController;
import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.smartdashboard.SmartDashboard;
import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj2.command.SubsystemBase;
import frc.robot.Constants.ArmConstants;
import frc.robot.Constants.ArmConstants.ArmPose;

public class ArmSubsystem extends SubsystemBase {

  private final SparkMax leftPivotMotor, rightPivotMotor;

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-01-25T20:33:52.983Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":227,"readers_count":226,"score":65.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":483580,"topic_slug":"tuning-arm-feedforward-pid","display_username":"Raíck","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":3,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":59829,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/tuning-arm-feedforward-pid/483580/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3492666,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-25T22:11:31.000Z","cooked":"
miguelsr:

we find kV by dividing 1 by the maximum angular velocity we found

This isn’t an appropriate way to find kV. “Max velocity” refers to motor free speed.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-01-25T22:11:31.000Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":226,"readers_count":225,"score":70.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":483580,"topic_slug":"tuning-arm-feedforward-pid","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/tuning-arm-feedforward-pid/483580/3","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3492682,"name":"Miguel Ramos","username":"miguelsr","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/miguelsr/{size}/244931_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-25T22:35:35.790Z","cooked":"

I imagine that the most appropriate way would be using sysid, but we didn’t think how we could apply this tool in an arm, I mean that, specifically in the code

Would there be any alternative to sysid?

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-01-25T22:35:35.790Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":243,"readers_count":242,"score":98.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":483580,"topic_slug":"tuning-arm-feedforward-pid","display_username":"Miguel Ramos","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":12381,"username":"Oblarg","name":"Eli Barnett","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49695,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/tuning-arm-feedforward-pid/483580/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3492683,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-25T22:36:04.905Z","cooked":"

Use ReCalc or tune manually. SysId works fine on an arm, though.

Alternatively, a better method to determine kS and kG is to place the arm at horizontal and increase voltage until the arm begins to move upwards, and then to decrease it until it begins to fall. The average between the “just begins to move up” and “just begins to fall” voltages should be a good estimation of kG, and half of their difference should be a good estimate of kS.

OK, we will retake the measurements as soon as possible and let you know

One more thing, the ReCalc outputs are in V*s/rad, to convert the through bore encoder output would the section below be valid? and would we need to do this conversion somewhere else?

public double getMeasurement() {
    return Math.toRadians(encoder.get() * 360 - ArmConstants.ARM_ENCODER_OFFSET);
  }

That looks like it could be right, you’ll have to try it and see. You should write a method to do the conversion instead of doing it inline with magic numbers.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-01-25T22:53:53.332Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":198,"readers_count":197,"score":44.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":483580,"topic_slug":"tuning-arm-feedforward-pid","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":49695,"username":"miguelsr","name":"Miguel Ramos","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/miguelsr/{size}/244931_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/tuning-arm-feedforward-pid/483580/7","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3493137,"name":"Max Morehead","username":"Max_Morehead","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/max_morehead/{size}/231937_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-26T18:14:07.320Z","cooked":"
miguelsr:

and we started trying to use the PID together, but for some reason, when the arm is in the vertical position (0 degrees) it has some oscillations, in addition to that when we are in horizontal and we go to vertical the arm, we have a large momentary overshoot , after a while, it corrects the overshot and returns to oscillating vertically

I think that video of the arm and details of the gearing/mechanics might help diagnose this. My first reaction to hearing this is that your arm is either undergeared or your PID controller is overtuned or both. Also, my comment that kA is unnecessary might be less true for arms that are undergeared; if you have less gearing then your mechanism’s rotational inertia (as seen by the motor) is a lot higher, so kA becomes more necessary. But for most teams I’d recommend increasing the gearing in that case.

Oblarg:

Alternatively, a better method to determine kS and kG is to place the arm at horizontal and increase voltage until the arm begins to move upwards

This is equivalent to the method described in my linked comment, but Oblarg described it better. I think when I wrote my comment I wanted to provide a process that could be stopped after any step. It was built off my experience that in 2023, 6662 had an arm that worked good enough that only used manually tuned kG and a P term. But again, our gearing was high enough to allow this. I think that given it sounds like you already have a built arm at the end of week 3, it might make sense to try out sysid.

Two other comments. One it’s generally recommend to use setVoltage instead of set when doing closed loop control as you’ll get more consistent behavior when your battery voltage sags (you’ll have adjust your constants accordingly). Second, I don’t think you’ll get good testing results if you clamp your output to 0.05 percent output, so I would slowly bump that up incrementally when you think it’s safe. Potentially that could even be what’s causing the oscillation.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-01-26T18:38:03.162Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":2,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":157,"readers_count":156,"score":61.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":483580,"topic_slug":"tuning-arm-feedforward-pid","display_username":"Max Morehead","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://instrumentationtools.com/recognizing-tuned-pid-controller-phase-shift/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Recognizing an Over-Tuned PID Controller by Phase Shift","clicks":6}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53784,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/tuning-arm-feedforward-pid/483580/8","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3493752,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-27T16:10:25.677Z","cooked":"
Max_Morehead:

It was built off my experience that in 2023, 6662 had an arm that worked good enough that only used manually tuned kG and a P term. But again, our gearing was high enough to allow this. I think that given it sounds like you already have a built arm at the end of week 3, it might make sense to try out sysid.

In my experience, an experimentally-determined kG and kS combined with a theoretical kV and kA from ReCalc will work well for any single-jointed arm. SysId is overkill, albeit instructive overkill with neat diagnostics.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-01-27T16:10:57.539Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":113,"readers_count":112,"score":57.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":483580,"topic_slug":"tuning-arm-feedforward-pid","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/tuning-arm-feedforward-pid/483580/9","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3493810,"name":"usbcd36","username":"usbcd36","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/usbcd36/{size}/2444_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-27T17:16:57.744Z","cooked":"
miguelsr:

when the arm is in the vertical position (0 degrees) it has some oscillations

Depending on where your encoder is, this might be due to backlash. As the angle of the arm is changing from horizontal to vertical to beyond, gravity takes up the backlash in the powertrain until the arm is nearly vertical, has little effect, no effect, then pulls the arm in the opposite direction as it goes over the top. The controller bobbles the arm back and forth, because the arm isn’t at setpoint, but also can’t be acted upon until the backlash in the powertrain is taken up. The code points to the encoder reading the arm directly – the worst case for this.

miguelsr:

in addition to that when we are in horizontal and we go to vertical the arm, we have a large momentary overshoot , after a while, it corrects the overshot and returns to oscillating vertically

How well does the arm track the position and velocity profiles, and what are the proportions of feedback and feedforward output? Are your acceleration or velocity limits too high for the arm to reach? Are they achievable at all angles, or just some?

@Max_Morehead pointed out that the duty cycle is being limited to 5% (e.g., ~0.6 volts; line 76), which means that it probably isn’t possible to achieve the profile velocity or acceleration, especially the acceleration at horizontal (where the force due to gravity is greatest) and the deceleration at vertical (where the force due to gravity is the lowest). It’s surprising that this works at all with the output clamped so low, but maybe the arm is geared extremely conservatively?
